Now, handling dynamic memory? 

Probably, since the input can be of variable length, but assuming that the input is not too big (like up to 1000 digits?), we can use fixed size arrays. 

Let me outline the steps in code:

#include <stdio.h>

#include <string.h>

#include <stdlib.h>

int main() {

    // Read a and b from input

    char line[1000]; 

    fgets(line, sizeof(line), stdin); 

    // Split into a and b 

    char *token = strtok(line, " "); 

    char a_str[500]; 

    strcpy(a_str, token); 

    token = strtok(NULL, " "); 

    char b_str[500]; 

    strcpy(b_str, token); 

    // Compute x 

    int len_a = strlen(a_str); 

    int len_b = strlen(b_str); 

    int x = (len_a > len_b) ? len_a : len_b; 

    // Pad a and b 

    char a_padded[x+1]; 

    char b_padded[x+1]; 

    // Pad a with leading zeros 

    int i; 

    for (i=0; i <x - len_a; i++) {

        a_padded[i] = '0'; 

    }

    strcpy(a_padded + (x - len_a), a_str); 

    a_padded[x] = '\0'; 

    // Pad b with trailing zeros 

    strcpy(b_padded, b_str); 

    for (i = len_b; i <x; i++) {

        b_padded[i] = '0'; 

    }

    b_padded[x] = '\0'; 

    // Now compute the sum 

    int result_digits[x +2]; // max needed is x+1 (if carry) 

    int carry =0; 

    int len_result =x; 

    for (i=0; i <x; i++) {

        int digit_b = b_padded[i] - '0'; 

        int digit_a = a_padded[x -i -1] - '0'; 

        int sum = digit_b + digit_a + carry; 

        int digit = sum %10; 

        carry = sum /10; 

        result_digits[i] = digit; 

    }

    if (carry) {

        result_digits[x] =1; 

        len_result =x+1; 

    }

    // Now form the sum_str as the reversed digits array 

    char sum_str[len_result +1]; 

    for (i=0; i < len_result; i++) {

        sum_str[i] = '0' + result_digits[len_result -1 -i]; 

    }

    sum_str[len_result] = '\0'; 

    // Now process the second part 

    // Count the digits 

    int count[10] = {0}; 

    for (i=0; i < len_result; i++) {

        int digit = sum_str[i] - '0'; 

        count[digit]++; 

    }

    // Check how many have odd counts 

    int flag =1; 

    int cnt =0; 

    for (i=0; i<10; i++) {

        if (count[i] %2 !=0) {

            cnt++; 

            if (cnt >1) {

                flag =0; 

                break; 

            }

        }

    }

    // Determine output 

    if (flag) {

        printf("First\n"); 

    } else {

        if ( (len_result %2) ==0 ) {

            printf("Second\n"); 

        } else {

            printf("First\n"); 

        }

    }

    return 0; 

}

Wait, but in C, the array sum_str is declared with a variable length (len_result +1). But in C99, variable-length arrays are allowed, but some compilers may not support them. Alternatively, we can use a fixed size array.

Let me adjust the code to use fixed arrays. 

Let me set a maximum input length, say 1000 digits. 

So:

#define MAX_LEN 1000 

int main() {

    char line[MAX_LEN]; 

    fgets(line, MAX_LEN, stdin); 

    char a_str[MAX_LEN]; 

    char b_str[MAX_LEN]; 

    // split into a and b 

    char *token = strtok(line, " "); 

    strcpy(a_str, token); 

    token = strtok(NULL, " "); 

    strcpy(b_str, token); 

    int len_a = strlen(a_str); 

    int len_b = strlen(b_str); 

    int x = (len_a > len_b) ? len_a : len_b; 

    char a_padded[MAX_LEN]; 

    char b_padded[MAX_LEN]; 

    // pad a 

    for (i=0; i <x - len_a; i++) a_padded[i] = '0'; 

    strcpy(a_padded + (x - len_a), a_str); 

    a_padded[x] = '\0'; 

    // pad b 

    strcpy(b_padded, b_str); 

    for (i = len_b; i <x; i++) b_padded[i] = '0'; 

    b_padded[x] = '\0'; 

    // compute sum 

    int result_digits[MAX_LEN]; 

    int carry =0; 

    int len_result =x; 

    for (i=0; i <x; i++) {

        int digit_b = b_padded[i] - '0'; 

        int digit_a = a_padded[x -i -1] - '0'; 

        int sum = digit_b + digit_a + carry; 

        result_digits[i] = sum %10; 

        carry = sum /10; 

    }

    if (carry) {

        result_digits[x] =1; 

        len_result =x+1; 

    }

    // form sum_str 

    char sum_str[MAX_LEN]; 

    for (i=0; i < len_result; i++) {

        sum_str[i] = '0' + result_digits[len_result -1 -i]; 

    }

    sum_str[len_result] = '\0'; 

    // process second part 

    int count[10] = {0}; 

    for (i=0; i < len_result; i++) {

        int digit = sum_str[i] - '0'; 

        count[digit]++; 

    }

    int flag =1; 

    int cnt =0; 

    for (i=0; i<10; i++) {

        if (count[i]%2 !=0) {

            cnt++; 

            if (cnt>1) {

                flag =0; 

                break; 

            }

        }

    }

    if (flag) {

        printf("First\n"); 

    } else {

        if ( (len_result %2) ==0 ) {

            printf("Second\n"); 

        } else {

            printf("First\n"); 

        }

    }

    return 0; 

}
